ns1:criterion.ns1:name: data structures
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Doesn't know the difference between Array and LinkedList
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Able to explain and use Arrays, LinkedLists, Dictionaries etc in practical programming tasks
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Knows space and time tradeoffs of the basic data structures, Arrays vs LinkedLists, Able to explain how hashtables can be implemented and can handle collisions, Priority queues and ways to implement them etc.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Knowledge of advanced data structures like B-trees, binomial and fibonacci heaps, AVL/Red Black trees, Splay Trees, Skip Lists, tries etc.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: algorithms
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Unable to find the average of numbers in an array (It's hard to believe but I've interviewed such candidates)
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Basic sorting, searching and data structure traversal and retrieval algorithms
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Tree, Graph, simple greedy and divide and conquer algorithms, is able to understand the relevance of the levels of this matrix.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Able to recognize and code dynamic programming solutions, good knowledge of graph algorithms, good knowledge of numerical computation algorithms, able to identify NP problems etc.
ns1:criterion.ns1:comment: Working with someone who has a good topcoder ranking would be an unbelievable piece of luck!

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: systems programming
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Doesn't know what a compiler, linker or interpreter is
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Basic understanding of compilers, linker and interpreters. Understands what assembly code is and how things work at the hardware level. Some knowledge of virtual memory and paging.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Understands kernel mode vs. user mode, multi-threading, synchronization primitives and how they're implemented, able to read assembly code. Understands how networks work, understanding of network protocols and socket level programming.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Understands the entire programming stack, hardware (CPU + Memory + Cache + Interrupts + microcode), binary code, assembly, static and dynamic linking, compilation, interpretation, JIT compilation, garbage collection, heap, stack, memory addressing...

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: source code version control
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Folder backups by date
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: VSS and beginning CVS/SVN user
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Proficient in using CVS and SVN features. Knows how to branch and merge, use patches setup repository properties etc.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Knowledge of distributed VCS systems. Has tried out Bzr/Mercurial/Darcs/Git

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: build automation
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Only knows how to build from IDE
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Knows how to build the system from the command line
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Can setup a script to build the basic system
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Can setup a script to build the system and also documentation, installers, generate release notes and tag the code in source control

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: automated testing
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Thinks that all testing is the job of the tester
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has written automated unit tests and comes up with good unit test cases for the code that is being written
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Has written code in TDD manner
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Understands and is able to setup automated functional, load/performance and UI tests

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: problem decomposition
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Only straight line code with copy paste for reuse
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Able to break up problem into multiple functions
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Able to come up with reusable functions/objects that solve the overall problem
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Use of appropriate data structures and algorithms and comes up with generic/object-oriented code that encapsulate aspects of the problem that are subject to change.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: systems decomposition
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Not able to think above the level of a single file/class
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Able to break up problem space and design solution as long as it is within the same platform/technology
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Able to design systems that span multiple technologies/platforms.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Able to visualize and design complex systems with multiple product lines and integrations with external systems. Also should be able to design operations support systems like monitoring, reporting, fail overs etc.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: communication
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Cannot express thoughts/ideas to peers. Poor spelling and grammar.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Peers can understand what is being said. Good spelling and grammar.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Is able to effectively communicate with peers
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Able to understand and communicate thoughts/design/ideas/specs in a unambiguous manner and adjusts communication as per the context
ns1:criterion.ns1:comment: This is an often under rated but very critical criteria for judging a programmer. With the increase in outsourcing of programming tasks to places where English is not the native tongue this issue has become more prominent. I know of several projects that failed because the programmers could not understand what the intent of the communication was.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: code organization within a file
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: no evidence of organization within a file
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Methods are grouped logically or by accessibility
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Code is grouped into regions and well commented with references to other source files
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: File has license header, summary, well commented, consistent white space usage. The file should look beautiful.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: code organization across files
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: No thought given to organizing code across files
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Related files are grouped into a folder
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Each physical file has a unique purpose, for e.g. one class definition, one feature implementation etc.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Code organization at a physical level closely matches design and looking at file names and folder distribution provides insights into design

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: source tree organization
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Everything in one folder
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Basic separation of code into logical folders.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: No circular dependencies, binaries, libs, docs, builds, third-party code all organized into appropriate folders
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Physical layout of source tree matches logical hierarchy and organization. The directory names and organization provide insights into the design of the system.
ns1:criterion.ns1:comment: The difference between this and the previous item is in the scale of organization, source tree organization relates to the entire set of artifacts that define the system.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: code readability
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Mono-syllable names
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Good names for files, variables classes, methods etc.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: No long functions, comments explaining unusual code, bug fixes, code assumptions
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Code assumptions are verified using asserts, code flows naturally - no deep nesting of conditionals or methods

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: defensive coding
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Doesn't understand the concept
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Checks all arguments and asserts critical assumptions in code
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Makes sure to check return values and check for exceptions around code that can fail.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has his own library to help with defensive coding, writes unit tests that simulate faults

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: error handling
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Only codes the happy case
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Basic error handling around code that can throw exceptions/generate errors
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Ensures that error/exceptions leave program in good state, resources, connections and memory is all cleaned up properly
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Codes to detect possible exception before, maintain consistent exception handling strategy in all layers of code, come up with guidelines on exception handling for entire system.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: IDE
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Mostly uses IDE for text editing
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Knows their way around the interface, able to effectively use the IDE using menus.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Knows keyboard shortcuts for most used operations.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has written custom macros

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: API
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Needs to look up the documentation frequently
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has the most frequently used APIs in memory
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Vast and In-depth knowledge of the API
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has written libraries that sit on top of the API to simplify frequently used tasks and to fill in gaps in the API
ns1:criterion.ns1:comment: E.g. of API can be Java library, .net framework or the custom API for the application

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: frameworks
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Has not used any framework outside of the core platform
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has heard about but not used the popular frameworks available for the platform.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Has used more than one framework in a professional capacity and is well-versed with the idioms of the frameworks.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Author of framework

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: requirements
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Takes the given requirements and codes to spec
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Come up with questions regarding missed cases in the spec
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Understand complete picture and come up with entire areas that need to be speced
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Able to suggest better alternatives and flows to given requirements based on experience

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: scripting
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: No knowledge of scripting tools
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Batch files/shell scripts
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Perl/Python/Ruby/VBScript/Powershell
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has written and published reusable code

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: database
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Thinks that Excel is a database
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Knows basic database concepts, normalization, ACID, transactions and can write simple selects
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Able to design good and normalized database schemas keeping in mind the queries that'll have to be run, proficient in use of views, stored procedures, triggers and user defined types. Knows difference between clustered and non-clustered indexes. Proficient in use of ORM tools.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Can do basic database administration, performance optimization, index optimization, write advanced select queries, able to replace cursor usage with relational sql, understands how data is stored internally, understands how indexes are stored internally, understands how databases can be mirrored, replicated etc. Understands how the two phase commit works.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: languages with professional experience
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Imperative or Object Oriented
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Imperative, Object-Oriented and declarative (SQL), added bonus if they understand static vs dynamic typing, weak vs strong typing and static inferred types
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Functional, added bonus if they understand lazy evaluation, currying, continuations
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Concurrent (Erlang, Oz) and Logic (Prolog)

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: domain knowledge
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: No knowledge of the domain
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has worked on at least one product in the domain.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Has worked on multiple products in the same domain.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Domain expert. Has designed and implemented several products/solutions in the domain. Well versed with standard terms, protocols used in the domain.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: tool knowledge
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Limited to primary IDE (VS.Net, Eclipse etc.)
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Knows about some alternatives to popular and standard tools.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Good knowledge of editors, debuggers, IDEs, open source alternatives etc. etc. For e.g. someone who knows most of the tools from Scott Hanselman's power tools list. Has used ORM tools.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has actually written tools and scripts, added bonus if they've been published.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: languages exposed to
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Imperative or Object Oriented
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Imperative, Object-Oriented and declarative (SQL), added bonus if they understand static vs dynamic typing, weak vs strong typing and static inferred types
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Functional, added bonus if they understand lazy evaluation, currying, continuations
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Concurrent (Erlang, Oz) and Logic (Prolog)

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: codebase knowledge
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Has never looked at the codebase
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Basic knowledge of the code layout and how to build the system
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Good working knowledge of code base, has implemented several bug fixes and maybe some small features.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has implemented multiple big features in the codebase and can easily visualize the changes required for most features or bug fixes.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: knowledge of upcoming technologies
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Has not heard of the upcoming technologies
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has heard of upcoming technologies in the field
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Has downloaded the alpha preview/CTP/beta and read some articles/manuals
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has played with the previews and has actually built something with it and as a bonus shared that with everyone else

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: platform internals
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Zero knowledge of platform internals
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Has basic knowledge of how the platform works internally
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Deep knowledge of platform internals and can visualize how the platform takes the program and converts it into executable code.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Has written tools to enhance or provide information on platform internals. For e.g. disassemblers, decompilers, debuggers etc.

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: books
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Unleashed series, 21 days series, 24 hour series, dummies series...
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Code Complete, Don't Make me Think, Mastering Regular Expressions
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Design Patterns, Peopleware, Programming Pearls, Algorithm Design Manual, Pragmatic Programmer, Mythical Man month
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs, Concepts Techniques, Models of Computer Programming, Art of Computer Programming, Database systems , by C. J Date, Thinking Forth, Little Schemer

ns1:criterion.ns1:name: blogs
ns1:criterion.ns1:level0: Has heard of them but never got the time.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level1: Reads tech/programming/software engineering blogs and listens to podcasts regularly.
ns1:criterion.ns1:level2: Maintains a link blog with some collection of useful articles and tools that he/she has collected
ns1:criterion.ns1:level3: Maintains a blog in which personal insights and thoughts on programming are shared
